articles.headline: Partisan Fever in Senate Likely to Rise
articles.snippet: Republicans will no doubt try to exact revenge against the Democrats who humiliated them with the strong-arm move to limit filibusters.
articles.abstract: Republicans will no doubt try to exact revenge against the Democrats who humiliated them with the strong-arm move to limit filibusters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will get a short-term lift for his nominees, judicial and otherwise, but over the immediate horizon, the strong-arm move by Senate Democrats on Thursday to limit filibusters could usher in an era of rank partisan warfare beyond even what Americans have seen in the past five years.

articles.headline: A Trading Tactic Is Foiled, and Banks Cry Foul
articles.snippet: When the Commodity Futures Trading Commission clarified reporting disclosure rules, financial institutions that had found a way around the regulations were brought up short. An outcry ensued.
articles.abstract: When the Commodity Futures Trading Commission clarified reporting disclosure rules, financial institutions that had found a way around the regulations were brought up short. An outcry ensued.
articles.lead_paragraph: What country are you in? Where is your business located? In what country did your trade take place?

articles.headline: F.C.C. to Weigh Allowing Cellphone Use on Flights
articles.snippet: The Federal Communications Commission’s plan is already opposed by many passengers and by flight attendants, although some airlines in Asia and Europe already offer cell service.
articles.abstract: The Federal Communications Commission’s plan is already opposed by many passengers and by flight attendants, although some airlines in Asia and Europe already offer cell service.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission said on Thursday that it would consider changing its rules to permit the use of cellphones and other wireless-data devices during airline flights. If approved, the change is certain to delight some passengers but frustrate many others.
articles.byline: By Edward Wyatt and Nick Bilton

articles.headline: Derelict in Detroit, and Hard to Sell
articles.snippet: Two winning bidders failed to complete the purchase of a long-abandoned Packard plant on 40 acres on the city’s east side, but a third bidder could still come through.
articles.abstract: Two winning bidders failed to complete the purchase of a long-abandoned Packard plant on 40 acres on the city’s east side, but a third bidder could still come through.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — It is the ultimate abandoned building in the city that has become America’s unofficial capital of blight.

articles.headline: Service Members Left Vulnerable to Payday Loans
articles.snippet: Officials say many predatory lenders have steadily found ways around the Military Lending Act, a law that was meant to stop them.
articles.abstract: Officials say many predatory lenders have steadily found ways around the Military Lending Act, a law that was meant to stop them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Petty Officer First Class Vernaye Kelly winces when roughly $350 is automatically deducted from her Navy paycheck twice a month.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: California Encouraged by Health Plan Enrollment
articles.snippet: Nearly 80,000 people have enrolled in health plans through California’s online marketplace, at a rate of several thousand a day in November — a sizable increase over a month ago.
articles.abstract: Nearly 80,000 people have enrolled in health plans through California’s online marketplace, at a rate of several thousand a day in November — a sizable increase over a month ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly 80,000 people have enrolled in health plans through California’s online marketplace, at a rate of several thousand a day in November — a sizable increase over a month ago, state officials said on Thursday.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas and Andrew Pollack

articles.headline: Once at Kennedy’s Side, Now at One Another’s
articles.snippet: Fifty years after President John F. Kennedy’s death, many of the men who took part in his funeral are reuniting for a second, and possibly final, time.
articles.abstract: Fifty years after President John F. Kennedy’s death, many of the men who took part in his funeral are reuniting for a second, and possibly final, time.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALLEN, Tex. — In the early morning darkness of Saturday, Nov. 23, 1963, at approximately 04:30 hours, Tim Cheek, a 20-year-old Marine assigned to body bearer duty, was one of eight enlisted men to carry President John F. Kennedy’s coffin, first into the East Room of the White House, and then back out the next afternoon; up the steps to the Capitol Rotunda and then down the next morning; into St. Matthew’s Cathedral and, then, out to the horse-drawn caisson waiting in the street.

articles.headline: No Release in Sight for Film Exploring China’s Violence
articles.snippet: “A Touch of Sin,” the new film by the celebrated art house director Jia Zhangke, won a best screenplay award at Cannes in May. When it will be shown in China, however, is anybody’s guess.
articles.abstract: “A Touch of Sin,” the new film by the celebrated art house director Jia Zhangke, won a best screenplay award at Cannes in May. When it will be shown in China, however, is anybody’s guess.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Jia Zhangke screened his new movie, “A Touch of Sin,” for a small group of journalists in his office last August, he said the film would make a round of foreign film festivals in the autumn and then, if all went well, be released on Nov. 9 in China. Now, with winter approaching, there is still no indication that the film will be shown in Chinese theaters.
